name: Resonance
description: When a brilliant particle physicist dies unexpectedly, the race is on to secure his terrible new technology before it falls into the wrong hands. The lives of four playable characters become entangled as they fight against the clock to find the dead scientist’s secret vault.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows ME, 2000, XP or Vista  Processor: Pentium or higher  Memory: 64 Mb RAM Hard Disk Space: 1G Free Space Video Card: Supports all DirectX-compatible video cards  DirectX®: DirectX 5 or above  Sound:  Supports all DirectX-compatible sound cards

reviews.review_text: LOVED IT! Multiple endings, multiple characters, inteligent puzzles (it's not like fantasy click & point games where the puzzles are contrived...in a fun way), amazing story, great dialoge & (best of all?) physics! I play A LOT of point & click games & this has gone straight to my top 5, I recommend that everyone plays it.  (This may not be a very helpful review but there are enough of those, this is a great game. Play it.)
Fantastic p&c adventure with an excellent contempory story with a sci-fi flavour

There's a really good story and some very nice ideas in here, unfortunately wrapped up in a game that trips itself with those same ideas. Definitely a case where less would have been more.  Starts off well enough, the introduction to the four central characters is well done with a couple of mini puzzles to work out and an introduction to the idea of timed segments. Unfortunately the game goes awry shortly after as we meet the most annoying janitor ever and he actively gets in your way with his incompetence.  This wouldn't be unusual for a game like this and would be forgivable were it not for the simultaneous introduction of 'short term memory', which basically means dragging environmental cues into your memory so you can talk to people about them. A nice idea, but it overcomplicates the game far more than it needs to as you work out that the item you need to talk about is 3 screens away for the fourth time. The game would be much improved by dropping the STM idea (it largely gets forgotten later in the game anyway so maybe the devs worked that out for themselves) and just including the relevant option in conversation. Other daft complications such as asking which way to turn a wrench when there is only one way it can turn at any time offer more pointless frustration for the player.  On the more positive side a few nice puzzles (if you like cryptography and maths) are very satisfying, unfortunately they lead in to one f the most frustrating parts of the game in Anna’s second timed scene. Not being happy to be a point and click game the devs saw fit to introduce the need for fast mouse wiggling, which wouldn’t be so bad if it were not for the fact that one slip sends you all the way bad to have to re-listen to Anna shrieking over and over again each time. This is an annoyance that reappears at various times as the rewind sends you back way too far.  Some more lovely little puzzles, including one that really makes the most of the teamwork between all four follows before the story really kicks into gear, I won’t spoil anything but suffice to say it is worth persevering this far for it. Unfortunately the final notes are a few more frustrations born form the need to pixel-hunt and trial-and-error conversations round out the game.  Overall the devs at XII would do well to look at the Blackwell series(from the same publishers) for cues on how to add a little innovation and variety into an adventure game without going overboard, more restraint next will definitely help to prevent the game from getting in the way of the story as it does here.  I'm recommending it because there are some nice ideas and there is a good story in there, just be aware before you play it that you will get frustrated and you will question why on earth some design decisions were made that way as you play.

This game is overlooked. It puts a new spin on the adventure game genre with a 4 character mechanic utilizing both long and short term memories. Basically you use the character's prior knowledge (memories( as tools in the environmental puzzles, as opposed to relying solely on contrived or forced inventory items that might be included in other games.   It is highly innovative which deserves praise in itself, but one of the most amazing feats of this game, is in spite of having 4 characters with various memories, I used a walkthrough maybe a single time on this game. To say a little about me, i'm a fan of adventure games, many classics (too many to list, but to give you an idea: Gabriel Knight, Sam and Max, Day of the Tentacle, Broken Sword, The Longest Journey, Monkey Island and many, many more. However, most of thet ime I resort to a walkthrough to varying degrees when I get stuck.   The story was compelling all the way through and art style really captured the mood. I wanted to leave this review for long time adventure game fans, to not overlook this game.
What a beautiful game! If only there were more games just like this one...

As always Wadjeteye Games have delivered another amazing game with a new inventive UI and a awesome story with many twists and turns as well as asking big questions about how all new technology has the capacity for peace, but there wil always be people who will use it for their own purposes.  I highly recommend this and any other game by Wadjeteye Games to anyone who loves point and click adventure games.

To be honest I was rather sceptical about this game at the beginning: I thought it would be another point-and-click quest with tons of pixel-hunting. Well... It is actually one. But it is not a disadvantage! Not here. The game has much more interesting benefits then the average quests. First of all, it has somewhat unique mechanic of long-time and short-time memories. Saw a homeless in a subway? Why not to remember and talk about him with a neighbor on the car? Was a witness of a blackout in a whole city? Well, that is worth remembering and discussing weeks after. And so on and so forth. Pretty much memory combinations you can make to proceed further. Secondly, you can operate four different characters at the same time. Not so surprising for a quest game of 2012? But how you unite the characters with their abilities - it affects the story. Much more impressive now, huh? And one last thing, the game has an amazing storyline and a wonderful voice acting that helps you to live a story of 'Resonance' like you are an important part of it too.  So, my opinion: 'Resonance' is one of 'must have' and 'must be played' games.
Only took 3 hours to complete but enjoyed every second.

I used to love point and click adventure games a long, long time ago. Back when they were in vogue and Sierra was a household name, point and click adventure games were some of the most desireable games out there.  These days, only small indie developers bother to make point and click adventure games and with very few exceptions, the games are not that great. Usually the story is lackluster as the indie developer is usually one guy who is wearing too many hats and isn't really an expert with any of them.   This game is a bit of an exception. The story is pretty awesome. It's fresh and exciting and the ending is twisty. I have to admit, I really enjoyed this game. If you are a fan of point and click adventure games, or if you just want to try one out, this one is certainly worth it.   Well done!

Resonance is a nice kick to the adventure gaming face. The game as a whole does a lot of things right, character interaction and development is great, each character has a distinctive background and the presentation does well to give you just enough you remain curious to what's going on. Puzzles which is normally not my cup of tea was rewarding to solve with a tiny drop of challenge in the mix.  The story immediately had me thinking of the upcoming 'Watchdog' game by ubi as a lot of the themes play into it. If your an old school adventure gamer get this, if your an avid gamer all about good games regardless of it's age..get this.
Top notch storie telling through a digital medium

This game has its nice moments and it is unfortunate I have only thumb up or thumb down as a rating. But after all in a game like this, without graphics, without much innovation, it is a plot I am mostly interested in. And this plot is very weak.  Aside from one twist (that can be seen a mile in advance), it is as naive as a bad Hollywood movie. Characters are flat, setting is not really believable, and half of the problem they face felt like retelling of r/politics. I feel niche games need higher standards.

I loved Resonance! One of the best point and click adventures I've played in a really long time. The story is terrific. At the end of the 2nd act, there's a huge plot twist that hit me like a ton of bricks.The voice acting is really good. It's a long game. I got stuck in one part where I had to cheat multiple times to get through it. Except for that part in the middle of the game, it was a solid challenge, but not overwhelming. There's multiple endings and optional, hidden things to do. I really liked how any object in the evironment and even memories along with inventory items can be used as a topic of conversation with npc's. Also, there's some more hands on stuff besides all the point and clicky stuff. There's a part where some goon is climbing a rope to get to the chick and the mouse needs to be rapidly pushed up and down to simulate the cutting of the rope. Also, there're a couple of 'hacking' parts where a reporter needs to get information from computer systems that were really well done. Adventure fans should play this game immediately. I highly recommend. Resonance is awesome!
A game in the style of mid-1990s adventure games for no particular reason. Hmm, why am I compelled to forgive its graphical and presentational flaws??? Ten outta ten.

Good puzzles, interesting story and characters, satisfying ending(s).  Though I got frustrated in some parts of the game I can't deny my satisfaction after solving the puzzles and eventualy the mystery behind Resonance. A great old-school point and click adventure game.

Excellent scenario and old school graphics for this point & click. The only regret on this game is that it is fairly poor in user-friendlyness departement : moving your character properly and using the miscs game interfaces needed more work for smoother result.

I'm definitely a fan of the point-and-click adventure, so in that way this may be a tad biased, but I certainly enjoyed this game. A good plot (as long as you don't overthink it!) with some puzzles that get you thinking, but not enough to bring you out in a cold sweat for the most part. It seems that some of the harder problems can be dodged so that you can continue if things just get too much at those points...but where's the fun in that? :-)  I've played Gemini Rue from Wadjet Eye as well, and though the story genre and mood are quite different, this is of a similar quality in my opinion...maybe a little better.

It's a nice game, but it's not always clear what you have to do, even with the clues. The storyline is great and the characters are interesting. To have four simultaneous playable characters is sometimes enjoyable and some other times tedious.
Surprisingly satisfying, sometimes even logical adventure game. Story draws you in quickly without laying it on too thick.

Really fun little adventure game here, it won't change your mind on the genre, but if you've ever enjoyed an adventure game, this shouldn't be missed. Sweet little combination of innovative and classic.

This game is for anyone that likes Thrillers and Sci-Fis. You play through 4 different characters and... Oh the plot twists... I can still remember the moment when I almost fell from my chair. The story is really awesome, like any of the point and click should have. It is totally worth it's money. If I could forget it, discover it, buy it and play it again, without a single doubt!   9,5 / 10
Great plot, original story telling and smart puzzles

If you like point & click adventures, I highly recommend this one. The story is really intriguing and the characters are well written. The game has some original gameplay mechanics (long & short term memory) for puzzle solving. So you wont constantly face the standard 'here's a list of dialog options, hammer at em till you pick the right one' situations. You're actually required to do some logical thinking. Also you're not forced to be completely linear. In the 'act 2' of the game you get the freedom of choosing in which order and (to some extent) how you complete your tasks. And hey, 2 different endings. You'll come across with some optional puzzles too, that'll flesh out the game world and explains the stories of the characters better for you, which I found awesome.  Great adventure game about science and conspiracy with heaps of good plot twists.

Pretty, good writing, good voice acting, decent length and relatively frustration-free point and click adventure gameplay.  Cared about the characters and the plot had twists that were genuinely suprising.

Other than the graphics, this is one of the best adventure games I have ever played. The story is fast paced and engaging. The puzzles were challenging and logical. The music and voice acting were good. There were some new and interesting game mechanics. The first is the short-term and long-term memory system. Second is switching between the four main characters in order to solve puzzles. The character animations are good, each character has their own set of expressions. Some animations like walking around are jumpy like old 16 bit games. The biggest negative to this game is the graphics resolution, about the same as an old fashioned Sierra title from the early 90's. Since some of the puzzles and game mechanics rely on visual cues, this detracts from the overall playing experience. What is most impressive about this game is that it provides a good experience in spite of this primitive graphics resolution.

A fun game with a great story and two endings that do a great job of avoiding the oh-so-typical black and white morality most games revel in today. The characters are interesting, and the sci-fi tech exciting- so, basically, it's awesome!
Once again WE did it. Big fan.

Wadget Eye adventure games have REALLY high quality stories. Their older adventure games go through a learning curve in puzzle design and UI but sticking through it is always worth it for the story. This game is no exception. I'm only 1.8 hours in and already entranced and sucked in. Even to people who normally dislike the adventure game mechanic, I highly recommend picking up a walkthrough and going through it just to experience the tale. (Not to say that their puzzles aren't fun. I think they're fun but it's not for everyone.)
Old-fashioned point-and-click adventure with a lot of good ideas. Not too long, but enjoyable enough. Very good voice acting. If this is your bag, you will definitely want to grab Resonance.
Honestly amazing. The story was great, the puzzles, more often than not, made sense through logical reasoning. It was a thoroughly enjoyable sci-fi/conspiracy game.
